content.description: Start on the low chalked hold with feet above the dirty ledge. Trend up and right to top out.

Good pump generating traverse. Be extremely careful to test each hold as the wall is full of loose rock, especially the top out on the left side of the wall. Begin traverse far right on blocky blunt arete. Stay off the ground and stay off the top loose holds and move left over some bushes, poison ivy and possibly water (during the first 7-8 months of the year.) Entire traverse to the top out is approximately 80-100 feet, but I have not measured for accuracy. [EDIT - the ground level has changed due to the work from the Metroparks clearning out the dirt, weeds, poison ivy and small trees. It is now much easier to protect with crash pads].Its not great, but it is climbing on real limestone, in Northwest Ohio. Could certainly use some cleaning and clearing of the brush under the wall.
content.protection: crash pads and spotters can be helpful.
content.location: Begin far right on the blocky arete.

content.description: A simple and enjoyable fun problem
content.location: Start on the stepping stool ledge in the middle of wall at the base, over and up to the left.

content.description: Start on lowest crimp with feet hooked high to the left, off the low ledges. Work up to the left for top out.

Start on big hold beneath drill hole. Go straight up avoiding ledges, using only side pulls and gastons on left side of hole with feet out right until the deceivingly solid top block. Top out right as per Whitehouse Full Traverse.
Limestone wall near Whitehouse Quarry and Sledding Hill.
